title: Gustaf Erik Hasselgren
text:
Gustaf Erik Hasselgren (15 November 1781 — 9 March 1827) was a Swedish painter and <a href="etcher">etcher</a>. He specialized in Biblical and historical subjects.
Biography.
He was born in <a href="Stockholm">Stockholm</a>. His father, Erik Gustaf Hasselgren, was the local head of the security guard; a position akin to police chief. From 1798, he studied with <a href="Pehr%20Hillestr%C3%B6m">Pehr Hilleström</a> at the <a href="Royal%20Swedish%20Academy%20of%20Fine%20Arts">Royal Swedish Academy of Fine Arts</a>, where his works, largely historical in nature, were awarded several medals, including the Academy's first silver medal in 1803. He became an agré (a type of member-candidate) in 1804 and received a major travel scholarship in 1806. 
He first went to Berlin, where he stayed for a year, but was not able to accomplish much, due to an illness. This was followed by three years in <a href="Dresden">Dresden</a> and one year in Vienna, before he settled in Italy. He remained there for five years; becoming associated with the German art colony and befriending <a href="Johann%20Friedrich%20Overbeck">Johann Friedrich Overbeck</a>, one of the major figures in the <a href="Nazarene%20movement">Nazarene movement</a>. 
During his travels (in 1812), he had been named a full member of the Academy. In 1816, he returned to Sweden to succeed Hilleström as Professor of figure painting. The following year, he married the artist . 
His larger works include a "Resurrection of Christ", which is in <a href="Saint%20James%27s%20Church%2C%20Stockholm">Saint James's Church, Stockholm</a>, and a depiction of "<a href="Ragnar%20Lodbrok">Ragnar Lodbrok</a>", which was commissioned by King <a href="Charles%20XIV%20John">Karl XIV Johan</a>. His works may also be seen at the <a href="Nationalmuseum">Nationalmuseum</a> and the .
Hasselgren died in Stockholm on 9 March 1827.
